questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the role of physiological pH of the vagina? acid under the influence of estrogen. reappear at puberty.

options.A: The acidic pH of the vagina helps prevent the growth of pathogenic organisms.
options.B: Doderlein’s bacillus is responsible for maintaining the acidic pH by converting glycogen to lactic
options.C: Doderlein’s bacillus appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth and disappears after 10–14 days, to
options.D: An increased vaginal pH can predispose to infections such as vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.explanation: candidiasis. Correct answer: D) An increased vaginal pH can predispose to infections such as vulvovaginal candidiasis. Explanation: Vulvovaginal candidiasis (yeast infection) typically occurs in a physiological pH of vagina (acidic environment) and is not associated with an increased vaginal pH . The infections that typically occur in increased vaginal pH are Trichomoniasis and bacterial vaginosis . Normal physiological pH of vagina i.e. 3.8-5.0 (acidic) helps prevent the growth of pathogenic organisms (Option A) . Certain microorganisms thrive when vaginal pH is increased. Vaginal pH is maintained by the Doderlein’s bacillus which converts glycogen to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen (Option B) . Doderlein’s bacillus appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth, disappears after 10–14 days, and reappears at puberty when estrogen levels rise. (Option C) Table: Vaginal pH, Symptoms, and Indications pH Symptoms Diseases 3.8 to 4.4 Normal Physiological pH - 3.8 to 4.4 Itching, burning, white thick curdy discharge Vulvovaginal candidiasis 4.5 and above Itching, fishy smell, thin homogeneous discharge (white to grayish) Bacterial vaginosis 5.5 and above Green or yellow, frothy discharge; foul odor; pain with sexual intercourse, vaginal soreness Trichomoniasis Reference: Pubmed DC Dutta Textbook of Gynaecology Pg. 5, Pg. 134-135

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman who is sexually active presents to the clinic with complaints of a fish-smelling vaginal discharge that has been ongoing for the past week. On physical examination, there is a thin, white, and creamy vaginal discharge. The physician suspects bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following criteria would not be required to establish the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis using Amsel's criteria?

options.A: Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination

questions.explanation: criteria. In fact, bacterial vaginosis is typically associated with a decrease in lactobacilli. The Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis require the presence of at least three out of the following four criteria: Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination (Option A) Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 (Option B) Positive whiff test with KOH (fishy odor) (Option D) Thin, white homogeneous vaginal discharge Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Gynaecology Pg. 125-126

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of a creamy fish-smelling vaginal discharge that has been ongoing for the past 2 weeks. On physical examination, the physician notes no signs of inflammation and a thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge. A vaginal wet mount was done which is attached below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disease? diagnosis.

options.A: The causative organism is Gardnerella vaginalis.
options.B: Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis with PCR can be used as a method of
options.C: Oral metronidazole is the treatment of choice given 500 mg for 7 days.
options.D: Demonstration of more than 10% of typical cells as seen in the slide is diagnostic.

questions.explanation: diagnostic. epithelial cells embedded with coccobacilli Gardnerella vaginalis . (Option A) Presence of >20% of clue cells in total cell population is diagnostic of Bacterial vaginosis. Diagnosis Methods and Treatment for Bacterial Vaginosis Diagnostic Methods Amsel's Criteria Presence of clue cells (more than 20% of the total cell population) Positive whiff test Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge Microscopic Examination Detection of clue cells in vaginal smear Molecular Methods Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis using PCR (Option B) Treatment: First-Line Treatment (Option C) Oral Metronidazole: 500 mg BD for 7 days Tinidazole 2 g orally for 3 days Alternative Treatment Clindamycin 300 mg orally BD for 7 days Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Gynaecology Pg. 125-126

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a yellowish-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She reports painful urination and pain during intercourse & no itching. On speculum examination, her vulva and vaginal walls appear inflamed. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: of vaginitis in women of reproductive age. Symptoms include : Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening Painful urination Pain during intercourse Recurrent infections Inflamed vulva Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages ("strawberry cervix") Candida albicans: ( Option B) Characterized by a scanty, white, curdy vaginal discharge Intense vulvovaginal itching present leading to erosions causing splash dysuria and dyspareunia Gardnerella vaginalis: ( Option C) Characterized by a foul-smelling, thin, gray-white, or green-yellow vaginal discharge Absence of itching, dysuria, or dyspareunia Neisseria gonorhhea( Option D) It does not typically cause vaginitis alone. It can cause cervicitis, whose symptoms can overlap with that of vaginitis. Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Gynaecology, 8th Edition, Page 135, 125, 126

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a sudden, profuse, and offensive vaginal discharge. On examination, her vulva is inflamed and her vaginal walls are red and inflamed with small, punctate, hemorrhagic spots as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true in this scenario?

options.B: Male sexual partners to be treated at the same time

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Male sexual partners to be treated at the same time Explanation: The presence of motile, pear-shaped flagellated trichomonas on wet mount microscopy is a characteristic feature of Trichomonas vaginalis . Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection, so the patient's sexual partner should also be treated. Feature Trichomonas vaginalis vaginitis Candida albicans vaginitis (Moniliasis) Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) pH ≥ 4.5 < 4.5 ≥ 4.5 Other Symptoms Itching and irritation in and around vaginal opening, dysuria Intense vulvovaginal pruritus (out of proportion to the discharge), dyspareunia, splash dysuria Generally not accompanied by itching or inflammation but may be associated with complications such as PID and pregnancy complications Diagnosis Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy Identification of mycelia, pseudohyphae, and spores by direct smear and staining (methylene blue) Amsel's four diagnostic criteria (three of four are sufficient): (1) Homogenous vaginal discharge, (2) Vaginal pH > 4.5, (3) Positive whiff test, (4) Clue cells Microscopy Motile, pear-shaped, flagellated organisms Hyphae and buds, spores Clue cells (>20% of cells)

questions.question: A 25 year old woman presents with a thick, white vaginal discharge as shown in the image. Pelvic examination reveals tenderness. A wet mount microscopy shows the presence of mycelia and pseudohyphae. Which of the following statements is true?

options.D: Lactobacilli aids in the growth of this organism

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Presence of pruritus Explanation: Women with thick, white vaginal discharge with the presence of pseudohyphae is Candidal vaginitis . Intense vulvovaginal itching is a hallmark symptom of this condition . Risk factors for developing this infection include: Diabetes Pregnancy Use of broad-spectrum antibiotics Immunosuppression and steroid use Clinical features: Vaginal discharge Intense itching of the vulva and vagina Pain during intercourse (dyspareunia) due to soreness Examination Findings: A thick, white, curd-like discharge Pelvic examination may be tender, and removing the white discharge can reveal multiple sore spots Diagnosis : On KOH mount, the filamentous form of mycelia and pseudohyphae of the fungus can be seen. Low dose OCPs (Option C) is no longer thought to increase the risk of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Lactobacilli (Option D) inhibit the growth of fungi in the vagina.

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of itching, burning, and a thick, white vaginal discharge. The symptoms started a few days ago and have progressively worsened. She denies any fever or abdominal pain. On examination, there is vulvar erythema and a thick, curdy white discharge adherent to the vaginal walls. She is sexually active and uses oral contraceptives for birth control. A wet mount preparation reveals findings as shown in the image. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Topical Miconazole Explanation: The patient's symptoms and examination findings along with presence of budding yeast and pseudohyphae on a wet mount preparation confirms vaginal candidiasis . Miconazole is an azole antifungal agent effective against Candida species. It is used as a first-line treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis either as topical cream (2% or 4%) or a vaginal suppository (100 mg or 200 mg or 1200 mg). Recommended Regimens for Uncomplicated Vulvovaginal Candidiasis: Clotrimazole 1% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 7–14 days or 2% cream for 3 days Miconazole 2% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 7 days or 4% cream for 3 days Vaginal suppository (one suppository daily) : 100 mg for 7 days or 200 mg for 3 days or 1,200 mg for 1 day Butoconazole 2% cream 5 g intravaginally in a single application Oral Agent - Fluconazole 150 mg orally in a single dose Recommended Regimens for Complicated Vulvovaginal Candidiasis: An additional 150-mg dose of fluconazole given 72 hours after the first dose. Adjunctive treatment: 10–14 days of topical

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman presents with severe vaginal itching, thick white discharge, and significant vulvar swelling and redness that have persisted for two weeks. She has a history of uncontrolled diabetes and has had three similar episodes in the past six months. On examination, the vaginal mucosa appears erythematous and edematous. Microscopic examination reveals yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: of severe symptoms, recurrent episodes, and uncontrolled diabetes that predisposes her to more severe infections. Uncomplicated vs Complicated Vulvovaginal Candidiasis: Uncomplicated VVC Complicated VVC Symptoms: Mild to moderate and rare in occurrence Symptoms: Recurrent and severe Caused by Candida albicans Non-albicans candida (C.glabrata, C.tropicalis) In immunocompetent individuals In Immunocompromised individuals, eg., diabetics, HIV, on immunosuppressants. Reference: DC Dutta Gynaecology 8th Ed., Pg.136

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with frothy, malodorous vaginal discharge and vulvar itching. On examination, vaginal pH is elevated (>4.5), and wet mount microscopy reveals motile trichomonads. What is the appropriate management regarding treatment of her male sexual partner?

options.A: No treatment is necessary for the male partner
options.B: Male partner should be treated with metronidazole or tinidazole
options.C: Male partner should receive routine screening but no treatment is necessary
options.D: Male partner should be treated with topical antifungal cream

questions.explanation: Male partners are often asymptomatic carriers and should be treated with metronidazole or tinidazole to prevent reinfection of the female partner. Treatment schedule: Metronidazole 200 mg thrice daily orally for 1 week or a single dose of 2 g. Tinidazole single dose 2 g orally is equally effective. Same regimen for both partners. The male partner should use a condom during intercourse until the female partner's treatment is completed. Male partners should also be treated in cases of vaginal candidiasis where the partner is treated with topical nystatin. In case of bacterial vaginosis, treatment of male partner is not necessary. Option A Male partners can be asymptomatic carriers and can transmit the infection back to the female partner even after her treatment. Treating the male partner helps reduce the risk of reinfection. Option C: Screening identifies asymptomatic carriers, but treatment is essential to prevent transmission and recurrence of the infection between sexual partners. Option D: Topical antifungal creams are used to treat fungal infections like candidiasis, not protozoal infections like trichomoniasis. Reference: DC Dutta Gynaecology 8th Ed., Pg.135, 136.

questions.question: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother, for itching and a burning sensation in the genital area for the past few days. She has also noticed a malodorous, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The mother mentions that her daughter has been practicing good hygiene, and there has been no recent illness or use of antibiotics. The physical examination reveals erythema and slight swelling of the vulva, with a foul-smelling discharge. There is no fever or systemic illness. What is the most likely cause of the child’s symptoms?
questions.explanation: cause of vaginal symptoms in prepubertal girls. Due to lack of estrogen, the vaginal defense is lost and the infection occurs easily, once introduced inside the vagina. Etiology of Nonspecific vulvovaginitis: Presence of foreign body in the vagina Associated intestinal infestations—threadworm being the most common. Rarely, more specific infection caused by Candida albicans or Gonococcus may be implicated. Clinical Features Pruritus- varying degree Vaginal discharge Painful micturition On inspection: soreness of the vulva, labia minora may be swollen and red Investigations Direct microscopy and gram staining of vaginal discharge Culture in Stuart’s media Stool examination- to rule out intestinal infestations Vaginoscopy- for foreign body Treatment If cause is unknown- Simple perineal hygiene. In cases of soreness or after removal of foreign body, estrogen cream is to be applied locally, every night for two weeks. When the specific organisms are detected, therapy should be directed to cure the condition. Option a) Bacterial vaginosis- Gray white to green yellow white discharge, thin, adherent homogeneous in consistency, positive Whiff test (Fishy amine) Option b) Candidiasis- Thick curdy white discharge Option c) Trichomoniasis- Gray, yellow or green, thin, frothy, adherent discharge, has unpleasant odor Reference: DC Dutta Gynaecology 8th Edition Pg 133-134

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman with multiple sexual partners presents with vaginal discharge, lower abdominal pain, and dysuria. She has cervical motion tenderness and purulent vaginal discharge as shown in the image. Empirical treatment is started. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation: inflammatory disease (PID), commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae . Azithromycin is the empirical treatment as it covers both. Metronidazole (Option A) is the first-line treatment for trichomoniasis and bacterial vaginosis. Clindamycin (Option C) is used in the treatment of trichomonas vaginalis, intra-abdominal infections, lower respiratory tract infections, and gynecological infections (gram-positive aerobic + gram-positive and gram-negative anaerobic coverage) Fluconazole (Option D) is primarily used in the treatment of candidiasis Reference: DC Dutta Gynaecology 8th Edition Pg 135

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the hospital with complaints of vaginal dryness, burning, and discomfort during sexual intercourse over the past year. She also reports increased urinary frequency and occasional dysuria but has had no urinary tract infections confirmed by culture. She has been postmenopausal for 12 years and has not used hormone replacement therapy. On physical examination, the vaginal epithelium is noted to be pale, thin, and friable with reduced vaginal elasticity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Vaginal mucosa is thin due to deficiency of estrogen and is more susceptible to infection and trauma leading to atrophic vaginitis. There may be desquamation of the vaginal epithelium which may lead to formation of adhesions and bands between the walls. Clinical Features: Yellowish or blood stained vaginal discharge Discomfort, dryness, soreness in the vulva Dyspareunia. On Examination: Evidences of pruritus vulvae. Vaginal examination is often painful and the walls are found inflamed. Diagnosis : Mainly clinical, however senile endometritis may coexist and carcinoma body or the cervix should be excluded prior to therapy. Treatment: Improvement of general health and treatment of infection if present should be done. Systemic estrogen therapy may be considered if there is no contraindication. This improves the vaginal epithelium, raises glycogen content, and lowers vaginal pH. Intravaginal application of estrogen cream by an applicator is also effective. About one-third of the vaginal estrogen is systemically absorbed. Reference: DC Dutta Gynaecology 8th Edition Pg 136-137
